p: In Northern Norway, the Saami were subjected to violence more than the general population; 22% Saami women experienced sexual violence [ 58]. Several findings from Sweden and Norway indicate that a major part of Saami population has experienced ethnic discrimination and it has negative implications to mental well-being and quality of life [ 59, 60]. Several important cultural and social factors, such as living in Saami core areas, involvement in reindeer herding, Saami as a native language, strong family ties, and communality, seem to protect Saami from mental health problems and provide resilience towards ethnic discrimination [ 60â€“ 62].
